thread.title: H.S. boys soccer: Dumont defeats Westwood, 5-0
thread.title_full: H.S. boys soccer: Dumont defeats Westwood, 5-0

title: H.S. boys soccer: Dumont defeats Westwood, 5-0
text:
Pages: 1 2 > display on one page 
WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP - The Huskies were hyped to get their chance at revenge when they traveled to Westwood High School Oct. 1 to take on the Cardinals. 
Junior midfielder James Ashun and the Huskies had this game circled on their calendar because Westwood beat Dumont, 3-1, in the first round of last year's state tournament, behind a three-goal barrage from the Cardinals in the second half. 
In this game, however, it was the Huskies who piled on the goals as they topped Westwood, 5-0. 
"We really wanted to prove something today," Ashun said. "We wanted to show them that [a win by them] wasn't going to happen again and it didn't." 
Early energy 
Both teams entered desperately searching for a win, to help enhance their chances at qualifying for the state tournament. 
Dumont's energy showed, and they were rewarded with an early goal. A little more than two minutes into the first half, Ashun found sophomore Richard Cabrera unmarked in the box, and Cabrera netted his first score of the season. 
The rest of the first half was filled with great opportunities, but no one could capitalize. The Cardinals drew a 30-yard free kick with 26 minutes to go until halftime. Junior defender Jackson Iorio sent a nice cross near the goal, but the ball sailed out of bounds, as nobody from Westwood could get a touch on it. 
Five minutes later the ball was kicked by the Cardinals into the box and stopped by a Huskies defender. As he was controlling it, the Westwood team and its fans all alleged that the back touched the ball with his hand. No call was made, and the ensuing argument led to one Cardinals' player being shown a yellow card. Despite all the chances, Dumont only led Westwood by a goal at halftime. 
Huskies add 2 more 
Westwood head coach Scott Murphy thought his team played a solid first session. He believed they controlled an important element of the game. 
"We played well in the beginning," he said. "The early goal let us down a bit, but we played our possession game pretty well." 
The Huskies doubled their lead nine minutes into the second half, when Ashun scored his fifth goal of the season. His shot deflected off a Westwood defender and landed on the opposite side of where the Cardinals goalie thought it would fall. 
Four minutes later Dumont struck again. Senior Eric Ramirez had some open space and decided to shoot. Westwood senior goalie Alan Miller dove to his left, attempting to make the save, but the shot was hard enough that the ball tipped off Miller's hand and crossed the line to put the Huskies up by three. 
Miller remained positive about the remainder of the season. 
"We need to keep working together as a team," he said. "Obviously, our record doesn't show where we want to be. There are a lot of growing pains going on, but it doesn't mean that our winning era is over." 
Communication 
Ashun added his second tally on the day when he faked out a Cardinals defender, and placed his shot in the right corner of the net to put Dumont up 4-0. With about five minutes to go, senior Zachary Naveo used a poor Westwood clearing pass to his advantage, scoring the team's fifth and final goal. 
The officials called the game with three minutes left, due to the rain. 
Huskies junior goalkeeper Michael Vietri finished with a clean sheet and six saves. Vietri had to sprawl out more than once to avoid fishing any balls out of the back of the net. Vietri said his team could use work on one vital skill. 
"We need to communicate more - that's been one of our problems," he said. "We've been picking it up a lot though and we just have to keep working hard." Â© 2015
